resources.string: It serves as the brain of your project. There are various models of Arduino boards, such as Arduino Uno, Arduino Nano, Arduino Mega, etc. Each one has different features and capabilities.

At the heart of every Arduino board is a microcontroller that runs the program you write. In most cases, these microcontrollers are from the AVR family by Atmel (now owned by Microchip) or ARM microcontrollers.
These are the pins on the Arduino board through which you can connect sensors, actuators, and other external devices. The pins can be configured as inputs or outputs as needed.
Power ports provide power to the Arduino board and connected devices. The most common ones are the 5V power port and the ground port (GND).
Most Arduino boards have a USB port that is used to upload the program to the board and for serial communication with a computer.
This component regulates the input voltage to provide a stable voltage to the board and connected devices.
A button that you can press to restart the program on the Arduino board.
Helps the microcontroller maintain precise timing synchronization. This is especially important to ensure accuracy in code execution.
